home.nostr_intro: Nostr is an open protocol for decentralized communication. It enables users to send and receive messages and other data over a network of relays.
home.protocol_basics_intro: Nostr is based on a simple but powerful event model. Every interaction in the network is an event with a defined structure.

event_structure.title: Event Structure
event_structure.id_desc: Unique ID (SHA256 hash of event data)
event_structure.kind_desc: Type of event (e.g., 1 for text message)
event_structure.content_desc: The actual content of the event

protocol_concepts.title: Core Concepts
protocol_concepts.nips_vs_kinds_explanation: NIPs (Nostr Implementation Possibilities) and Event Kinds are two different but important concepts in Nostr:

nips_section.title: What are NIPs?
nips_section.intro: NIPs (Nostr Implementation Possibilities) are proposals and standards that describe how various aspects of the Nostr protocol can be implemented. They help developers create compatible and interoperable applications.
nips_section.docs: NIPs are documents that describe various aspects of the Nostr protocol. They can propose new features, improve existing features, or provide best practices for implementing the protocol.
nips_section.website: On this website, you will find explanations and examples of various NIPs to help you better understand and use the Nostr protocol.

explanation.title: NIPs (Nostr Implementation Possibilities)
explanation.description: NIPs are technical specification documents that describe:
points: How new features should be implemented in the Nostr protocol
What standards all clients and relays must follow
How different types of data are structured
How communication between clients and relays works
explanation.example: For example, NIP-01 describes the basic protocol, while NIP-02 defines the format for contact lists.

event_kinds.title: Event Kinds
event_kinds.explanation_intro: Event Kinds are numerical identifiers that define the type and purpose of a single event. They are part of the actual data and determine:
purpose_points: What type of content an event contains
How clients should display the content
How relays should process the event
How long the event should be stored
event_kinds.connection_to_nips: Event Kinds are defined and standardized in various NIPs. For example, the basic Kinds 0-3 were established in NIP-01.

ranges.title: Kind Ranges and Their Meaning
ranges.regular: Regular events like metadata, text messages, and contact lists
ranges.regular_replaceable: Replaceable events where only the latest version is relevant
ranges.ephemeral: Short-lived events that don't need permanent storage
ranges.parameterized: Parameterized events for special use cases

event_kinds.metadata: Profile information like name, picture, and description
event_kinds.contacts: List of followed users and their preferred relays

implementation_example.title: Example of the Connection:
implementation_example.content: NIP-01 defines that an event of Kind 1 is a public text message. So when a client receives an event with kind: 1, it knows thanks to NIP-01 that it should display the content as a text message.

relays_section.title: What are Relays?
relays_section.intro: Relays are servers that forward messages and other data in the Nostr network. They act as intermediaries between clients and ensure that messages are delivered to the correct recipients.

clients_section.title: What are Clients?
clients_section.intro: Clients are applications that users use to interact with the Nostr network. They allow users to send and receive messages, publish data, and access information shared by other users.

mobile.title: Mobile Apps
mobile.description: For iOS and Android on the go

summary.title: Summary
summary.text: Nostr is a decentralized communication protocol based on relays and clients. NIPs provide the standards and proposals that help developers implement and extend the protocol. This website offers an introduction to Nostr and NIPs, as well as examples and explanations to help you better understand and use the protocol.

nip1.key_protocol_description: NIP-01 defines the fundamental concepts and mechanisms of the Nostr protocol. It is the cornerstone for all other NIPs and must be supported by all Nostr implementations.

overview.title: Overview
points: NIP-01 establishes the basic structure of events
Defines communication between clients and relays
Describes authentication and validation of events
Establishes the publish/subscribe model for data exchange

event_structure.title: Event Structure
event_structure.description: An event is the basic data unit in Nostr. Every action and piece of information is transmitted as an event.

id.title: ID
id.description: A SHA-256 hash of all other event fields. Serves as a unique identifier.
id.technical: Calculated from the serialization of event data (excluding 'id' and 'sig')

pubkey.title: Public Key
pubkey.description: The event author's public key in hexadecimal format.

created_at.title: Creation Timestamp
created_at.description: Unix timestamp of event creation in seconds.
created_at.technical: Must be a valid Unix timestamp

kind.title: Event Kind
kind.description: Numerical value defining the type of event.

tags.title: Tags
tags.description: List of tags for additional metadata and references.

content.title: Content
content.description: The actual content of the event as text.

sig.title: Signature
sig.technical: 64-byte Schnorr signature of the event ID value

relay_communication.title: Relay Communication
relay_communication.description: Communication between clients and relays occurs via WebSocket connections.

subscription.title: Subscription System
subscription.description: Clients can subscribe to events using filters:
filter_options: until: Events up to a timestamp

best_practices.title: Best Practices
client_practices: Connect to multiple relays for redundancy
Local caching of frequently used data
Implement exponential backoff for connection errors
